lines.text:
[Drunk and slurring]
I don't believe we've met. My name's Corbett, what's yours?
Gregory Boleslavsky.

[Taking affront]
Hey, now, wait a minute. I asked you a simple question and I expect a simple answer!
[Bewildered, he puts his hands in his pockets]
Want a drink?

[singing]
First she gave me ginger bread and then she gave me cake; and then she gave me creme de menthe for meeting her at the gate.
Sir, you're a baritone and a gentleman...
What this country needs is less ventilation and more smoke!

[Seeing Jerry being carried in]
Buck, is he hurt?
Oh, he's still alive, but a couple of bottles of scotch are dead.
I see you believe in signs.

[Drunkenly]
Mmmm, and all the signs point to three stars.
[THe camera pans in to a bottle of Henessey brandy]

[Drunkenly]
At the moment we're looking for a baritone.

[Taking offense]
I don't allow them in the place!

[In unison with Buck and Claire]
You don't?
[They leave]
I always said you were swell.
Perhaps you won't think so much longer because if being a modern husband gives you privileges, then being a modern wife gives me privileges.

[after Jerry reads a particularly snide column about him and Joan written by Demery]
Any statement to make to the press, Corbett?
Any statement I made to you wouldn't be fit to print.

[Officiously]
Well, I don't know. Yours is just a common case. When we're young, we want to marry for love, and when we're a little older, we marry a Rolls-Royce.
[Jerry punches him]
The only thing worse than a drunkard is a reformed drunkard.
single lives, twin beds and triple bromides in the morning.
Dear, why are you treating me with this devotion?
Devotion?
Well, about as much devotion as I'd show to a boa constrictor. Is it because I treated you badly once?
I didn't think you knew that you had.
I was young and egotistical, Jerry.
Well, what are you now?
Young and egotistical.
What trouble me is, have I a right to take a swell girl and make her my wife?
No.
Your charm is only exceeded by your frankness.
[recurrent line]
I think you're swell.

[Toasting]
To the ladies. They keep their hearts, and change their minds.
Oh, no. We keep our minds, but change our hearts!
